results.title: Screen Worlds opening : September 2009
results.brief_description:
On Thursday September 17, 2009 ACMI’s new permanent screen culture exhibition Screen Worlds, was officially launched. The red carpet, VIP event attracted world wide attention with the attendance of both internationally recognised and home grown guests and artists. Kicking off the formalities was ACMI’s Board President, John Thwaites, followed by ACMI Director Tony Sweeney, Oscar® Winning Actress Cate Blanchett, Victorian Arts Minister Lynne Kosky and Victorian Premier John Brumby.
Following this, the ribbon is cut and guests enter the exhibition for the first time.

results.title: Screen worlds : Interview with Ab Rogers
results.brief_description: British designer Ab Rogers is founder and head of a multi-disciplinary studio in London ARD (Ab Rogers Desgin). Ab visited ACMI in December 2008 and the Content Development crew interviewed him in relation to his design and intent behind the Screen Worlds exhibition. He spoke about the tendering process, the challenges of designing for the Federation Square space, his overall approach to design and a brief introduction to the three sections, Emergence, Voices and Sensation.

results.title: Screen sports development workshop
results.creator_credit: Public Programs - Events (Helen Simondson) and Paul Fletcher
results.brief_description:
The SCREENSPORTS event is a unique, entertaining and informative ‘CINEMA EXPERIENCE’. SCREENSPORTS represents an historic leap in the marriage of live performance and technology. It has the potential to be an ACMI flagship pioneering new international standards in screen-based performance. Based on the highly successful Theatre Sports;live improvisation performance the Screensports concept draws on screen culture and the screen as the basis for live improvisation.

A troupe of actors are thrown into virtual worlds utilising the ACMI template sets and the globecaster technology. The actors use these sets as a stimulus for fast and hilarious improvisation.
Screen sports will be fun and informative and appeal to a wide range of people.
In order to develop the Screensports performance it is crucial to conduct a creative development workshop to produce the content for the live performance.

results.title: Screen magazine. No. 8
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This is the United Nations”
Cinemagazine items: 1. UN at work on world wide system of road signs - An amusing allegory with cartoons by Steinburg. Explains how the two different systems used in Europe and America make it difficult for a travelling motorist to find their way outside their own country. 2. Eritrea federated to Ethiopia - Explains how United Nations investigated political problems posed by Eritrea, a former Italian colony on the Red Sea. The population was divided in race and religion; the land poor; political opinions strongly divided; some sought independence; some wanted union with Ethiopia. After the report by a UN Commission, the General Assembly decided to federate the country to Ethiopia within two years.

results.title: Screen Magazine. No. 25. A New future for Somaliland
results.creator_credit: United Nations. Dept. of Public Information
results.brief_description: Shows the work of the United Nations Advisory Council which was sent to Somaliland to advise the Italian Trusteeship Administration there. Help has been given on the development of a democratic government and judicial system, establishment of medical services, organisation of education, and the development of agriculture and industry.

results.title: Screen magazine. No. 23
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine item: Danish children build Greek school - In 1949 a United Nations Appeal was made for help in Greece. From Denmark came a plan to build and equip a complete school, paid for by Danish children. Students who were experts in building came to live and work in the Greek village, others had to learn the trade. The Danish students were joined by young people from other countries and in two years the school was finished.

results.title: Screen magazine. No. 22
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine item: Report from the Philippines - economic progress - Shows the assistance being given to the government of the Philippine Islands by the United Nations Technical Assistance Program. Also depicts the progress being made in the paper pulp industry and the development of Philippine Air Lines.

results.title: Screen magazine. No. 20. [Birthday for Eritrea]
results.brief_description: Eritrea, situated on the African continent and long known as an Italian colony, has become self-governing and has federated with Ethiopia. Through the work of the United Nationa, Eritrea’s future has been decided, for the first time in her history, by peaceful negotiations. Since the ending of colonial rule, Eritrea was guided by British adminstration, which organised an indigenous police force, established a new public school system and gave Eritreans a chance to administer justice in their local courts.

results.title: Screen magazine. No. 16
results.creator_credit: United Nations. Film Board and United Nations. Dept. of Public Information
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This is the United Nations”
The people of Afghanistan have followed a way of life that has changed very little in the past thousand years. In 1950 the Afghanistan Government, which has been making efforts to develop and improve the country, called upon the U.N. to help by providing technical assistance. This film describes how new knowledge and techniques have been introduce into industry and agriculture, resulting in increasing output and development of resources.
